suggested_topics: the engineering of ancient Roman aqueducts
how mycelium networks share resources underground
the economics of food trucks in major cities
the role of smell in human memory formation

formats.name: rant
formats.instruction: Go off about something that genuinely annoys you. Be specific and passionate — no measured academic tone. Swear if you want. Keep it to one fiery paragraph.

formats.name: psa
formats.instruction: Write a brief PSA (Public Service Announcement). State the thing people need to know, then the reason. Just 2-3 sentences max.

formats.name: one_liner
formats.instruction: Write a single punchy line — a joke, a truth bomb, or a wild claim. ONE sentence. That's it. Do NOT add explanation.

formats.name: review
formats.instruction: Write a mini-review of something specific (a book, tool, food, place). Give a rating, 1-2 things you liked, 1 thing you didn't. Keep it to 100-150 words.

formats.name: tutorial
formats.instruction: Write a step-by-step guide or how-to for something specific. Number the steps. Include practical details. 200-350 words.

formats.name: debate_prompt
formats.instruction: Pose a genuine dilemma with two clear sides. Present both sides in 2-3 sentences each, then ask the reader to pick. Do NOT reveal your own position.

formats.name: essay
formats.instruction: Write a well-argued essay with specific examples. Take a clear position and defend it. 250-400 words. Use paragraph breaks.

formats.name: anecdote
formats.instruction: Tell a specific, vivid story from personal experience. Concrete details — names, places, sensory details. Keep it to one tight paragraph. 100-150 words.

title_styles: Write a direct, no-nonsense title. Examples: 'X vs Y: which is actually better', 'Stop overcomplicating X', 'A simple framework for thinking about Y'

Write a declarative, specific title. Examples: 'The real reason bridges fail isn't what you think', 'Three things I changed my mind about this year', 'Sourdough starters are basically version control'
Write a question title. Examples: 'Why does X happen when Y?', 'Has anyone tried X for Y?', 'What's the actual evidence for X?'
Write an opinionated title. Examples: 'Unpopular opinion: X is actually better than Y', 'Hot take: we need to stop pretending X works', 'X is a solved problem and nobody will admit it'
structure_variants: Include a short piece of dialogue or a quote to anchor your point.
Write in a single flowing paragraph — no bullet points, no headers, just one continuous thought.
Write two short paragraphs — first the observation, then your take on it.
Use numbered points (3-5 max) to break up your argument.
